title: Unmanned Aerial Systems
description: The drone has become the defining weapon of modern warfare. What cost millions a decade ago now costs hundreds. This section covers everything from basic reconnaissance to advanced strike tactics, drawing from lessons paid for in blood on battlefields from Ukraine to the Middle East.

content.text: The battlefield has fundamentally changed. By late 2025, analysts estimate that drones account for 70% of all battlefield casualties in major conflicts. FPV drones alone now inflict up to 80% of losses at tactical depth. Ukraine, producing 200,000 FPV drones per month and targeting 4 million annually, became the first nation to establish a military branch dedicated exclusively to drone warfare when it created the Unmanned Systems Forces in June 2024.

The economics are staggering. A $400 FPV drone carrying a modified RPG warhead can destroy a $3 million tank. Ukraine's DOT-Chain procurement system now delivers drones directly from factory floor to fighting position, bypassing traditional military supply chains entirely. The gamification of kills—with points redeemable for advanced weapons—has turned drone warfare into something that resembles a lethal video game.

Understanding how drones communicate is essential for both operators and defenders. Most commercial drones use standardized protocols for control and video, making them predictable to those who know what to look for. Military and modified systems often employ proprietary or encrypted links, but all share common vulnerabilities that can be exploited.
UAS-Specific Protocols

rows: Current DJI platform standard with 15km range
Widely supported, customizable for DIY builds
Long-range RC link for FPV applications

content.text: Frequency Bands

Most COTS UAVs and their GCS use the same radio bands as Wi-Fi compatible devices to both control the UAV and transmit telemetry information from the UAV to the operator. More advanced and hobbyist platforms can be fitted with modems that transmit and receive data at 433 MHz or 915 MHz for extended range.

content.title: ISM Bands
content.text: Three of the four primary radio bands (2.4 GHz, 5.8 GHz, and 915 MHz) are part of the industrial, scientific, and medical radio bands. Per FCC Regulations, these do not require licenses for use to transmit. The FCC states that 433 MHz is a regulated band reserved for amateur radio operators, although internationally 433 MHz is considered an ISM band.

Understanding the capabilities and limitations of common drone platforms enables effective mission planning. The DJI Mavic series remains the predominant reconnaissance platform in modern conflicts, while purpose-built FPV drones have emerged as the primary kinetic strike platform.
DJI Mavic 3 Series

The DJI Mavic 3 Enterprise and Mavic 3T have become standard reconnaissance platforms. The triple-camera setup provides operators a clear battlefield view, detecting enemy movements, monitoring troop and vehicle movement, and identifying minefields. The Mavic 3 Pro can transmit real-time coordinates to artillery units for precise targeting.
FPV Drone Characteristics

The FPV drone has evolved from a hobbyist toy into the most cost-effective precision weapon in history. A basic setup—frame, motors, flight controller, camera, and goggles—costs $200 to $1,000. With AI-assisted targeting now boosting hit rates from 10-20% to 70-80%, these weapons have fundamentally altered infantry tactics. Frames have grown from 7 inches in 2022 to 10-13 inches by 2025, enabling heavier payloads including modified artillery rounds.

content.title: Security Considerations
content.text: The use of DJI drones by military forces is controversial due to security concerns. The U.S. Department of Defense banned the purchase of all commercial consumer drones for official purposes in 2018 and specifically blacklisted DJI in 2022. Consider OPSEC implications when using any network-connected commercial platform.

Implement a multi-team structure to enhance operational success. One team establishes relay locations, another plans and executes missions, a third deploys counter platforms, and a potential fourth facilitates communications between teams at a retransmission site.
Launch and Landing Protocols

Pre-designated primary, alternate, and compromised locations for launch and landing ensure flexibility and security. Avoid direct flights from launch sites to enemy locations and vice versa. Utilize sporadic or zig-zag movements in flight plans to obscure launch or landing zones.
Counter Team Coordination

Coordinate with all elements to understand friendly drone operations, threat locations, and objective locations. Maintain clear deconfliction between friendly UAS operations to prevent fratricide or mission interference.
Drone Modification Tactics

Modify hobbyist drones pre, during, and post-mission for increased survivability. Install software to obfuscate or remove drone ID information. Employ automated waypoints with pre-programmed missions to reduce reliance on controllers and vulnerability to jamming.
Secure Data Handling Procedures

items: Sanitize SD cards before and after use (simple deletion is insufficient, use secure erase)
Use blank tablet computers or cell phones without SIM cards kept in airplane mode
Pair devices with GNSS spoofing mobile applications but avoid internet connection
Install new software or scripts using air gap computers or removable media scanned by antivirus programs
Remove or disable all telemetry logging features that record flight paths

content.text: Drone Function Settings

content.title: Return-to-Home Hazard
content.text: Disable Return-To-Home function and set link lost setting to hover in place or land immediately. This prevents threats from tracking the drone back to launch location, preserving pilot anonymity. If RTH cannot be disabled, set the RTH point to a decoy location away from actual operating position.
Operational Safety

Never operate drones acquired from enemy sources, as they may be sabotaged, booby-trapped, or digitally altered to compromise operator security. Treat recovered drones as potential threats and handle them with caution, considering the possibility of sabotage or decoy tactics. Exploitation should only occur in isolated environments with proper technical support.

Match drone color patterns to specific environmental conditions for optimal camouflage. The goal is to minimize visual detection by matching the drone's appearance to the sky or background when observed from the ground.
Visual Camouflage
Avoid discontinuities in color patterns to minimize visual detection. Matte finishes reduce reflections that can catch sunlight and draw attention.
Night Operations

Disable or cover LED lights and paint drones fully black with matte colors to reduce visibility under moonlight or artificial light. Blacked-out drones are harder to identify with Night Vision but can still be detected with IR or thermal imaging. Fly at low altitudes and utilize obstructing terrain to minimize thermal observation.
Acoustic Signature Management
Be mindful of rotor noises and how they vary with temperature and weather conditions. Exploit atmospheric phenomena to minimize acoustic signature.

items: Approach target areas from downwind locations to suppress sound transmission
Utilize natural acoustic interference sources like traffic and natural sounds to disrupt acoustic detection
Avoid flying during atmospheric inversions, which amplify sound transmission over water or on warm evenings
Consider lower RPM propeller configurations that trade speed for reduced noise
Time operations to coincide with ambient noise peaks (traffic hours, industrial activity)

content.text: Decoy Tactics

Teams can use a smaller, secondary drone in an area where the adversary threat is unknown. Depending on the countermeasures targeting the decoy drone, mitigation TTPs can be employed with the primary drone. This may also provide a means of testing adversary C-UAS capabilities before committing primary assets. Approach the target with more than one drone from different vectors. This simulates a drone swarm that has the potential to surprise and confuse an adversary, forcing them to split their defensive attention.
Pre-flight OPSEC Measures

items: Avoid powering on the drone in areas where the camera may capture sensitive imagery as drones may start recording upon activation
Wait until the drone is safely away from the launch point before using the camera
Select take-off sites with consideration for the risk of adversary detection and indirect fire keeping a minimum distance of 1km from friendly forces
Cover the camera with tape or cloth until just before take-off to prevent unintentional recording of sensitive information
Verify all network/telemetry connections are disabled before powering on in sensitive areas

content.text: In-flight OPSEC Protocols

items: Fly the drone with the camera facing directly skyward during take-off and avoid viewing the surrounding area until reaching a safe distance
Use the camera for flight and recording only when the drone is approximately 500m from the take-off site
Cease recording at least 500m from the landing zone
Establish an offset pilot site located 100-150m away from the take-off site to minimize risk to the operator

content.text: Landing and Post-flight OPSEC Procedures

items: Conduct a mock landing near the ground before quickly moving to the actual landing zone to obfuscate the true landing location
Immediately power down the controller and drone upon landing
Move at least 500m away from the landing site
Refrain from approaching the site for at least 10 minutes after retrieving the drone
Avoid reusing the same take-off or landing zones to prevent detection patterns
Set Return to Home points to different locations for each mission

content.text: Countermeasures against GPS Jamming

Detect GPS jamming by monitoring for off-course movements, erratic behavior, or unresponsive controls. Flying without GPS reduces the risk of jamming but requires manual pilot corrections and may shorten battery life due to increased pilot workload.

items: Physically disconnect the GPS receiver module or cover the GPS antenna with aluminum foil to mitigate GPS jamming effects
DJI drones can be switched to Attitude Mode (ATTI) to maintain control during GPS jamming incidents
Practice ATTI mode flight regularly to maintain proficiency under degraded conditions
Consider fiber-optic tethered FPV systems which are immune to RF jamming entirely

content.text: Recognize the critical role of tactical flight profiles in optimizing aerial reconnaissance missions. These profiles aim to balance the need for detailed intelligence gathering with the imperative to minimize the risk of detection by hostile forces.
Optimal Altitude Selection

Depart from the misconception that flying at higher altitudes always provides the best vantage point. Instead, prioritize maintaining a lower altitude to enhance detail and reduce the risk of detection. Embrace the concept of treating natural elements such as trees as military crests, staying below their tops to avoid being silhouetted against the sky.
Disruptive Backgrounds

Employ natural features and terrain elements as disruptive backgrounds to conceal the presence of the drone. Mimic the tactics used by combat helicopters like Apache Longbows, which utilize natural cover to remain hidden from enemy observation. Experiment with flying closer to terrain features to exploit their disruptive effects on the drone's visibility.
Close-in Reconnaissance

Train operators to conduct reconnaissance at closer distances, particularly in permissive environments where the risk of detection is reduced. Emphasize the importance of maintaining situational awareness and adapting to changing threats. Explore the use of zoom capabilities at closer ranges to capture detailed imagery and intelligence without compromising operational security.
Background Noise Exploitation

Leverage background noise from sources such as highways or high-traffic roadways to mask the sound of the drone's motor and minimize acoustic detection by adversaries. Position the drone strategically between noise sources and target areas to obscure the sound of zooming in or adjusting altitude.

content.title: Experiment and Adapt
content.text: Encourage operators to experiment with different flight profiles and techniques to find the optimal balance between detail and stealth. Incorporate feedback from reconnaissance missions to refine tactics and improve operational effectiveness over time. Document successful techniques for the team's TTP library.

The following provides a standard format for requesting sUAS payload delivery support. While it includes elements of a CAS 9-Line, it may be used for deliveries other than ordnance against enemy positions. Examples include battery resupply and smoke obscuration. This format requires a read-back from the sUAS operator for every line, including all remarks or restrictions.
SPD Mission Types

There are three primary mission types for sUAS payload delivery: Attack missions for kinetic effects against enemy positions, Smoke missions for obscuration of enemy observation, and Resupply missions for delivering critical supplies to forward positions.
5-Line Format

rows: SkyRaider, this is Alpha 11, sUAS attack, over
Fire team in trench line / Drop on vs-17 panel

content.text: Line 5 Remarks and Restrictions

items: Desired Effects: Provided to ensure understanding of intent (e.g., obscure EN observation west of my position)
Time on Target (NET, NLT, At My Command): Timing restrictions for deconfliction
Alternate Signal: Air panel or other signal for at-my-command releases if radio communications fail
Routing Restrictions: May include checkpoints, stay-above, stay-below, or stay-away restrictions
Estimated Wind Speed and Direction: Assists operator in adjusting drop points for ballistic effects
Actions on Jamming: Instructions for what to do if sUAS link quality indicates possible enemy jamming

content.text: The kill zone has expanded dramatically. Reconnaissance and attack drones have made the airspace within 15 kilometers of contact lines essentially unsurvivable for conventional logistics. Ground drones now handle 90% of frontline supply runs in some sectors because wheeled vehicles become targets the moment they enter drone coverage. Russia has abandoned heavy armored columns for small assault teams on motorbikes and dune buggies. Survival requires understanding that 'passive' countermeasures demand constant, active work.
Dispersion

Tactical dispersion has been necessary on the battlefield since the introduction of breech-loading and repeating rifles over 150 years ago. sUAS proliferation introduces additional considerations. While dispersion may help reduce visual signature to enemy ground forces, it may actually increase visual signature to passing or loitering enemy sUAS. A widely dispersed force provides more chances, over a larger area, for visual or thermal detection within the system's field of view.

Dispersion may therefore primarily be a means to limit or slow collections on the size and composition of friendly forces and to protect them against the effects of dropped munitions, rather than a means to avoid outright detection from sUAS.
Visual and Thermal Camouflage

Avoiding detection will usually require some elements of camouflage. Camouflage should make it difficult for enemy sUAS operators to discern the presence of friendly forces through their systems' cameras and video screens. Most sUAS do not currently operate with timely, reliable automatic object detection software, though this capability is rapidly advancing. When AI-enabled detection becomes common, camouflage efforts will need to adapt to confuse those algorithms as well.

The most critical elements of visual signature are color, outline, motion, and heat. The first three are the traditional focus of camouflage efforts. Heat is added because many sUAS carry electro-optical/infrared cameras that provide the operator a colorized representation of objects' relative thermal radiation levels.
Thermal Masking

For ground forces, only marginal reductions in thermal radiation levels relative to the surrounding environment are usually attainable since human beings are warm-blooded. If thermal radiation cannot be reduced, it must be masked. Heat can be masked from a thermal sensor by placing an object or screen between its source and the sensor.

Individual measures like ponchos and thermal blankets are most effective only when used for limited periods, perhaps on-call when enemy sUAS is detected in the area. Longer continuous use will eventually produce a detectable heat signature wherever hot air escapes.

Standard camouflage netting, properly elevated, can achieve thermal masking even for large heat sources such as vehicles and generators. Double layering the netting can also help ensure the sensor cannot see through the netting to the heat sources below.
Physical Countermeasures

To counter direct attack drones, forces have developed physical countermeasures such as nets and wires that trigger early detonation, protecting troops and equipment. Cage armor and improvised mesh screens on vehicles can detonate shaped charge warheads before they impact the main armor.

content.title: Day vs Night Operations
content.text: Ground forces on the move will be most challenged to mask their heat signatures. It may be far more difficult to blend in with the surrounding environment's thermal colors at night than with its optical wavelengths during the day. Against prior expectations, it may be easier to avoid detection from most sUAS during the day than at night when thermal contrast is highest.

Active counter-UAS measures include electronic warfare, kinetic defeat, and interceptor systems. Modern forces employ a layered defense approach where signals intelligence identifies what drones are in the area, followed by jamming and electronic warfare, followed by physical protection and kinetic countermeasures.
Electronic Warfare

Jammers interfere with the communications link between the drone and the control station. By severing the transmission link, jammers cause the drone to enter its safety protocols, typically landing in place or navigating back to its launch location. GPS spoofing can redirect drones to false coordinates.

Out of 188 Shahed drones Russia launched in a November 2024 attack, 76 were downed kinetically while 95 were diverted by spoofing their satellite coordinates. Only 17 evaded all countermeasures. This demonstrates the effectiveness of layered electronic and kinetic defenses.
Portable C-UAS Systems
The Fiber-Optic Revolution

Fiber-optic FPV drones have rendered billions of dollars in electronic warfare investment obsolete overnight. These systems transmit control signals and crystal-clear video through hair-thin fiber-optic cables, making them completely immune to RF jamming. With ranges now exceeding 20 kilometers, they can strike deep behind lines with guaranteed signal integrity. The transition from radio to fiber represents one of the most significant tactical adaptations in modern warfare.

content.title: Fiber-Optic Countermeasures
content.text: Fiber-optic drones can only be stopped with kinetic means: shotguns, small arms, nets, or physical interception. Your multi-million dollar jammer is useless. The emphasis now is on what soldiers can carry—portable EW in backpacks and guns to shoot incoming FPV drones. Early visual and acoustic detection is your only warning.
Detection Methods

items: RF detection: Monitor for control link transmissions in common UAS bands
Acoustic detection: Listen for distinctive rotor noise signatures
Visual observation: Maintain air watch with designated observers
Radar: Small UAS radar can detect Group 1/2 drones at short range
EO/IR sensors: Thermal and visual cameras for tracking

content.text: Innovative tactics involving Enemy FPV drones have emerged, adding a new dimension to ambush strategies. These tactics often involve coordinated actions between FPV drone operators and ground-based support teams equipped with repeaters or relay drones. Understanding these enemy tactics enables development of effective countermeasures.
Reconnaissance and Coordination

Enemy FPV drone operators, often working in pairs, scout the area for potential targets. Ground-based support teams deploy repeaters or relay drones to extend the flight range of FPV drones, enabling them to surveil areas deep within friendly territory.
FPV Ambush Sequence

items: Utilizing extended flight range from repeaters, enemy FPV drones deploy to strategic positions near friendly rear areas
FPV drones land discreetly along roadways to observe key routes and monitor potential targets without arousing suspicion
An observer drone monitors the area and identifies potential targets such as support units or evacuation vehicles
When target is detected, observer drone relays information to FPV drone operators
Upon confirmation, FPV drone is activated and deployed to engage the target with precision
Ground-based teams with Mavic or fixed-wing drones monitor target movements for optimal timing

content.text: Tactical Considerations

To minimize the risk of detection, transportation and assembly of ambush teams are conducted at the smallest possible level, reducing their signature and avoiding detection by enemy surveillance. Assembly points are chosen to be as forward as possible, facilitating rapid deployment and maximizing the element of surprise.
Cloud RF Software

When dealing with poor range issues from a patrol base, Cloud RF emerges as a valuable tool for visualizing radio frequency scenarios using lidar data and employing link budget calculations. It serves as a comprehensive platform to understand the reasons behind signal loss or difficulties encountered in challenging environments.

In complex RF environments, Cloud RF allows users to simulate scenarios where the noise floor is raised, providing insights into potential jamming effects at the receiver station. For planning a maximum range one-way flight, input parameters such as transmitter power, antenna gains, frequency, and receiver sensitivity to analyze link performance.
Fresnel Zone

In radio communications, a Fresnel zone is one of a theoretically infinite number of concentric ellipsoids of revolution which define volumes in the radiation pattern. To maximize receiver strength, you need to minimize the effect of out of phase signals by making sure the strongest signals do not bump into anything. The strongest signals are closest to the direct line between transmitter and receiver and always lie in the 1st Fresnel Zone.

The first zone must be kept largely free from obstructions to avoid interfering with radio reception. As a rule of thumb, the maximum obstruction allowable is 40%, but the recommended obstruction is 20% or less. At 250 meters, the radius of the Fresnel zone for a 5.8GHz signal is still 1.8 meters. Anything within this zone, including the ground, will start to degrade your signal.
Free Space Path Loss

Free Space Path Loss is a mathematical equation used to calculate the attenuation of RF signals as they propagate through free space. Key factors include transmitter antenna gain, receiver antenna gain, system losses from connectors and transmission lines, signal frequency, and receiver sensitivity.
Repeater Types

rows: Fixed position, requires LOS to both ends
Mounted on Mavic or fixed-wing platform

content.title: Repeater Placement
content.text: When deploying a repeater, position it in direct line of sight to both the FPV drone and the ground control station, ideally at an elevated location that surpasses the surrounding terrain. For 1.3GHz video systems, maximum theoretical range in free space can exceed 70km with proper antenna configuration.

Analysis of large-scale FPV drone employment in modern conflicts reveals a significant expansion in tactical applications. Kamikaze drones now account for up to 70% of personnel and equipment losses at tactical depth. This section documents 19 named employment techniques observed in current operations.
Standard FPV Specifications
1. Classic Attack

The most common employment method. A reconnaissance drone locates the target and transmits coordinates to the FPV operator for destruction. Video confirmation of target destruction is provided by the reconnaissance drone. Requires: 1 recon drone operator, 1 FPV operator.
2. Free Hunt

FPV drones independently strike pre-identified objects and positions without real-time reconnaissance support. Operators work from previously collected intelligence on known enemy positions. Best for static targets with confirmed locations.
3. FPV Swarm

Mass attack using 5-12 kamikaze drones against identified targets. A reconnaissance drone locates targets and coordinates the mass strike. Can be combined with artillery and mortar fire for devastating combined effects. Requires: 5+ FPV operators, 1 recon operator.
4. Assault Group Escort

Sequential FPV attacks on enemy positions during assault team movement and offensive operations. The reconnaissance drone provides control and coordination between ground units and drone operators. Particularly effective for suppressing defensive positions ahead of advancing infantry. Requires: 3-5 FPV operators, 1 recon operator.
5. FPV Ambush

FPV drone lands and occupies a concealed position near roads with heavy traffic, intersections, or likely concentration areas, then executes surprise attacks on targets of opportunity. When paired with a relay drone: depth exceeds 5 km, wait time up to 6 hours (only control receiver active). At night, attacks can target vehicle headlights or use thermal-equipped FPV.
6. Combined Strike

Joint operation between FPV drones and bomber drones for comprehensive fire engagement. After FPV destroys or disables armored vehicles, the bomber drone drops munitions on personnel during evacuation. Alternative: bomber first immobilizes personnel/soft vehicles with drops, then FPV engages.
7. Double Strike

Sequential employment of multiple FPV drones with different warheads to defeat protected positions. First drone with shaped charge breaches the barrier. Second drone with thermobaric or fragmentation warhead engages personnel in interior spaces. Effective against bunkers and hardened positions.
8. FPV Trap

Booby-trapped drone variants designed to exploit enemy recovery attempts. Methods include: audio beacon to attract attention with remote detonation via relay drone; tilt-switch detonation when position changes; 20-50g embedded charge activated during disassembly; GPS beacon for follow-up strike on recovery location; chemical agent coating on drone body.

content.title: Recovered Drone Hazard
content.text: Never approach recovered enemy drones. Assume all downed enemy FPV drones are booby-trapped. Do not approach from the camera direction. Mark location, report to commander, wait for EOD specialist.
9. FPV Miner

Covert placement of anti-personnel mines, anti-tank mines, or disguised IEDs on rotation and evacuation routes. FPV drone delivers and places munitions near positions or on routes to destroy personnel and vehicles. Creates remote mining capability without exposing personnel.
10. FPV Sapper
Remote mine clearance by dropping munitions on or placing charges against exposed, unconcealed mines on roads and paths. Enables safe route clearance without risking EOD personnel.
11. FPV Drop

Munition drops from FPV drones to destroy personnel in the open or in light cover. Reconnaissance drone guides FPV to target. Cases documented of chemical agent munitions. Also used for friendly resupply drops to isolated positions.
12. FPV Dragon

Dispersal of incendiary mixture over enemy positions using FPV equipped with thermite charge (typically based on 120mm artillery incendiary round). Average dispersal height: 20-50m. Burn time: up to 2 minutes. Temperature exceeds 2300°C. Effective against personnel, vehicles, exposed ammunition, and equipment.
13. FPV Air Defense

Using FPV drones to intercept and destroy enemy reconnaissance drones and hexacopters. When radio-technical means detect UAV (altitude up to 3 km, speed up to 110 km/h), FPV drones launch for interception. Destruction via fragmentation charge detonation on approach or ramming. Radar operator provides target cueing.
14. FPV Saboteur

Covert pre-positioning of 4-6 kamikaze drones within 2-3 km of target by reconnaissance teams. Drones placed in standby mode, then remotely activated via GSM network signal to strike pre-loaded coordinates. Enables delayed attacks after team withdrawal.
15. FPV Mothership

Extended range operations using carrier UAV (fixed-wing or large multirotor) that also serves as relay. Payload capacity: 2-3 FPV drones. Range extension up to 60-70 km depending on carrier type. Unmanned surface vessels can also serve as FPV carriers for maritime operations.
16. Fiber-Optic FPV

FPV drones controlled via fiber-optic cable for guaranteed target engagement immune to EW jamming. Range: up to 10 km (some variants to 25 km). Characteristics: clear video to terminal phase, requires avoiding sharp maneuvers, must avoid fire sources along route. Only kinetic defeat is effective against these systems.
17. Building Clearing

Tiny whoop micro-drones (under 100mm diameter, under 50g) with prop guards for interior reconnaissance during urban assault operations. Flight time: up to 4 minutes. Indoor range: up to 500m. Used to detect enemy and clear rooms before entry.
18. FPV Loudspeaker

Psychological operations using FPV drones equipped with speakers to broadcast messages. Hover height: up to 50m. Used to demoralize personnel and encourage surrender by broadcasting that positions are surrounded and evacuation routes are under fire control.
19. Leaflet Drop

Information warfare using FPV drones for leaflet distribution. Payload: up to 2 kg (approximately 200 leaflets). Used for propaganda and psychological influence on military personnel and civilian population.

Countering FPV drones requires a comprehensive approach combining active and passive measures implemented both at unit level and by individual personnel. The number of drones on the front grows exponentially. Constant drone coverage has led to decentralization and reduction of forces at the front line. Where a platoon once held, now a squad suffices. Where there was a strongpoint, now three two-man positions.
Active Countermeasures

items: Locate and destroy drone operator teams: look for antennas, prepared launch sites, munition disassembly traces, packaging, inconspicuous vehicles, repeaters on tall buildings
Early UAV detection: visual, auditory, detector/analyzer signals, alerts from command or adjacent units
Electronic warfare suppression of control frequencies, video transmission, and satellite navigation
Reduce time in probable engagement zone through vehicle speed (enduro motorcycle at 80 km/h covers 5 km in 4 minutes)
Kinetic engagement: small arms fire, primarily shotguns (effective to 50m)
Mechanical defeat: net launchers at close range (20-30m)
Evasive maneuver: dispersion, taking cover, active movement in open terrain under threat

content.text: Passive Countermeasures

items: Fortification: anti-drone niches and foxholes, L-shaped bunker entrances, overhead protective nets and barriers
Position camouflage: irregular-shaped camo nets 0.3-0.5m from equipment in tree/bush shadows or inside damaged buildings, thermal covers, drone-perspective signature checks
Decoy positions with heat and light sources, vehicle mockups or disabled vehicles, simulated activity
Protective net/screen barriers along rotation and evacuation routes from fishing nets
Vehicle protection: overhead screens, cage armor, dome EW systems
Weather/terrain/time planning: operate during conditions unfavorable for drones
Smoke screens and obscuration of positions and movement routes

content.text: Camouflage Fundamentals

items: Camouflage from aerial observation using overheads, fabric nets, branches, grass, foliage. Positions are compromised by: plastic film, white bags, household trash, fresh earth, personnel movement
From the air you are less visible if you: do not move; are in shadow of structures; sit rather than lie (reduces profile); match uniform color to terrain; do not fidget or reflect light
Move and hide in shadows of trees and slopes. No sudden movements or running. Safer times: dusk, night, fog, rain. Thermal covers are relevant

Place and camouflage vehicles in tree lines, along/inside buildings and hangars, change positions, build simple camouflaged shelters. Cover vehicle glass to prevent glare. If enemy is north, park vehicles on south side of buildings

Do not park transport near positions; stage in concealed location for quick departure. Collect all trash in bags and designated pit. Scattered ration packaging, cans, bottles, plastic clearly expose positions. Launch your own drone quietly to check for signature indicators

Camo nets always needed in large quantities. When installing, vary configuration - the more unclear and diffuse the silhouette, the harder to detect. Satellite dishes heat up; hide in pits and camouflage from both day cameras and thermal
Create decoy positions with signature indicators. Install military vehicle mockups or disabled transport. Simulate activity. Light fires at night in empty shelters, place trench candles

content.text: Light and Sound Discipline

At night maintain light discipline. Cigarette glow, campfire, flashlight, headlights, phone screens attract drones like moths to flame. Conversations only in cover. Do not cluster with cigarettes when bored. Do not wander positions aimlessly. If called by command, inform another soldier. Primary detection criteria: movement by day and thermal signatures by night. Maintain silence, communicate in whispers and gestures, listen for sounds.
Fortification Best Practices

items: When digging positions, create lateral niche at bottom for protection from shrapnel during shelling, FPV strikes, and drops. Bunker exits in L-shape. Hang protective cover at shelter entrance. Build second bunker entrance (first may be buried by hit)
As FPV obstacles, prepare and secure cord anti-drone curtains from 4-5mm rope: length 6m, height up to 4m, 20cm spacing between hanging ropes
Alternative protection: install screens from cheap fishing nets (length up to 80m, height 4m) - invisible to operators. Build additional overheads and visors
Pre-position smoke grenades 20-30m from position for activation under drone kamikaze threat. Each soldier carries instant smoke grenades
Additional protection elements on vehicles (visors, cage armor, shields, nets, chains, 1cm rubber fragments on screws) increase crew and passenger survivability during drone attacks. Do not overdo it

content.text: Actions on Drone Detection

items: Always listen for sounds, sense the sky. Detection is first by sound (better at night), then visual. Use your ears and eyes. Report immediately. Treat all UAVs as hostile
Learn to distinguish Mavic from FPV by sound. Mavic is quieter and steadier, FPV is higher-pitched with sharp changes during acceleration
Plan movement based on analysis of enemy drone activity patterns in specific area (they know about gray time too)
Avoid open areas, move along tree lines, in built-up areas move building to building. Minimum 5m spacing in three-man teams. Move covertly by threes to control points

Reconnaissance drone is harbinger of FPV. If you detect enemy UAV while moving (including in vehicle), do not lead it to friendly positions. Take cover, wait, observe, do not reveal your unit's positions. In tree line, lean against tree trunk and freeze

During movement, maintain sky watch by sectors. Keep distance and note nearest cover (ruins, holes, tree lines, bushes) for sprint under drone threat. Shell crater as safe place becomes a grave. Do not cluster in one spot. Dispersion, maneuver, and speed
Hear FPV - immediately to cover. In the open - make sudden sharp movements. Exit operator's observation sector, dodge sideways during attack. Shuttle-run skills help. Practice
If drone is within 20-30m, do not freeze hoping it will not notice and pass by. Move! Survival is in reaction and movement

content.text: Vehicle Operations

items: Small arms fire is largely ineffective (small target, high speed). When shooting you are static, making operator targeting easier. At close range (to 50m), shotguns have best chance. Train on clay pigeons

Cases documented of operator toying with victims. If you are agile and skillfully evade, hide behind cover (40cm tree trunk works), and can attack drone by throwing objects - survival chances increase. Documented in practice
During vehicle movement, special attention to sky watch from rear and flanks (up to 80% of FPV attacks target rear and side of vehicles)

On dangerous sections, travel at maximum safe speed. Do not choose long routes. When kamikaze drone detected, pull off road (preferably to tree line or buildings), stop, and quickly disperse. Chance of evading FPV on highway is minimal
At vehicle stops, everyone exits very quickly, no clustering, no arguing about who unloads ammunition. Otherwise target priority increases. Time works against you

High-speed motorcycles, buggies, and ATVs with trained drivers improve survivability and logistics near the line. Electric versions provide silent movement and better crew alertness for early drone detection by sound

content.title: Extreme Driving
content.text: Extreme driving requires serious driver training. Practice day and night. Learn to identify and memorize landmarks by day and find them at night. Speed and unpredictability are your best defense against FPV drones while mobile.
